author: By Maggie Astor
title: Your Guide to Olympics Gymnastics: Floor Exercise
description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Tokyo, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
content: Women’s gymnastics is a marquee sport at the Summer Olympics, but otherwise doesn’t get much attention outside a dedicated group of fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: A largely maskless, sometimes violent protest against Sydney’s lockdown raises fears of superspreading.
description: Defying a statewide stay-at-home order and a worsening local outbreak driven by the Delta variant, 3,500 mostly maskless protesters clashed with police officers on Saturday in downtown Sydney, Australia’s largest city.
content: Defying a statewide stay-at-home order and a worsening local outbreak driven by the Delta variant, 3,500 mostly maskless protesters clashed with police officers on Saturday in downtown Sydney, Australia’s largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Christopher Flavelle
title: In Charleston, S.C., Saving Historic Homes Means Hoisting Them in the Air
description: A city known for extraordinary architecture is coming to terms with intensifying storms, a rising sea and streets that flood with distressing regularity.
content: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Over the course of 150 years, the generations who lived in the handsome house at 17 Logan St. shared a similar experience when walking out of the front door: There were four or five steps to descend, and then it was out onto the flat streets of one of the most beautiful, well-preserved — and flood-prone — cities in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A Russian shooter’s slip-up costs her the first gold medal of the Tokyo Olympics.
description: TOKYO — A terrible last shot cost a Russian shooter the first gold medal of the 2020 Olympics.
content: TOKYO — A terrible last shot cost a Russian shooter the first gold medal of the 2020 Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Flood Deaths in China Show Road Risks From Climate Change
description: At least four people died in a highway tunnel in central China that flooded at the same time as a subway tunnel after eight inches of rain fell in a single hour.
content: ZHENGZHOU, China — More than 200 cars were caught in a highway tunnel on Tuesday in central China when record-setting rainfall soaked the area. Torrents of water poured in the tunnel’s entrances, nearly filling it to the ceiling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Ashley Wong
title: After New York Tests a New Way of Voting, Other Cities May Do the Same
description: Elected leaders and voters in New York remain split over the ranked-choice system, but officials in Washington and elsewhere like the results.
content: The most high-profile experiment in ranked-choice voting in U.S. history just took place in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: ‘He Had a Life Before Death’: Remembering Emmett Till for the Child He Was
description: Emmett Till’s cousin Ollie Gordon recalled him as a jokester who “loved to make people laugh” as she reflected on their childhood together ahead of what would have been his 80th birthday.
content: Ollie Gordon was only 7 years old in August 1955, when the life that she shared with three generations of her family, including her cousin Emmett Till, on the South Side of Chicago was overturned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: The Right Sandwich for Right Now
description: Flavored with garlic mayonnaise, chiles, cilantro and lime, Kay Chun’s salt and pepper shrimp roll screams summer.
content: Hello from New York Times headquarters! I’m writing to you from my desk at the office, where I am for the first time since Covid banished me to my home, which I know makes me fortunate. It’s sort of thrilling to be here, even though it’s still empty, and to imagine the newsroom hive buzzing again. But, wow, I felt stress pangs as I left the house. What time would I be getting home? How will I make dinner in the fall when I’ll be commuting more often? Were my phone and keys even in my bag?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: For Older Adults, Home Care Has Become Harder to Find
description: Staffing shortages have long plagued the home care industry. But the pandemic has intensified the problem.
content: Almost daily, Terry Driscoll drives 40 minutes from her home in Yarmouth Port, Mass., to see her husband, Ken, in his memory care facility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Why America Isn’t Getting the Jan. 6 Investigation It Needs
description: Reaching any kind of national consensus about what happened that day now feels like as much of a fantasy as any false-flag conspiracy theory.
content: Unlike some of my colleagues, I wasn’t in the Capitol on Jan. 6, huddling in the hallways as a violent mob rampaged through the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Your Guide to Olympics Gymnastics: Uneven Bars
description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Tokyo, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
content: Women’s gymnastics is a marquee sport at the Summer Olympics, but otherwise doesn’t get much attention outside a dedicated group of fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hard
title: After a Republican outcry, Tennessee redirects vaccine outreach to teenagers, shifting it to their parents.
description: Two weeks ago, a campaign to encourage public school students to get vaccinated was halted when Republican elected officials complained that parents should make the decisions.
content: Tennessee health officials are resuming several programs to promote vaccinations for public school students, just two weeks after such efforts were halted because Republican elected officials had complained that parents should make the decisions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison Hope
title: Are You in an ‘Inter-Intimate’ Relationship?
description: For some couples, having different nonsexual intimacy preferences can be a strain on the relationship. Here’s how to meet in the middle.
content: Hugs. Back rubs. Cuddling. Holding hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles McDermid
title: Cambodia forces people into bleak quarantine camps as an outbreak rages.
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — The patients sit in packed ambulances before passing through metal gates. Once inside, they get a number, a thin blanket and a bedsheet to use as a mosquito net. Lights shine at all hours for surveillance. Each person is given four bottles of water a day and three small meals.
content: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — The patients sit in packed ambulances before passing through metal gates. Once inside, they get a number, a thin blanket and a bedsheet to use as a mosquito net. Lights shine at all hours for surveillance. Each person is given four bottles of water a day and three small meals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Jackie Mason, 93, Dies; Turned Kvetching Into Comedy Gold
description: He kept the borscht belt style of comedy alive long after the Catskills resorts had closed and eventually brought it, triumphantly, to Broadway.
content: Jackie Mason, whose staccato, arm-waving delivery and thick Yiddish accent kept the borscht belt style of comedy alive long after the Catskills resorts had shut their doors, and whose career reached new heights in the 1980s with a series of one-man shows on Broadway, died on Saturday in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. to Announce Troop Drawdown From Iraq, but Little Is Expected to Change
description: The deal appears to be the latest effort by the Iraqi prime minister to balance the needs and demands of the country’s two closest allies: the United States and Iran.
content: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s prime minister is heading to Washington this weekend to demand that President Biden withdraw all U.S. combat troops from Iraq, announcing to Iraqi media that the visit would “put an end to the presence of combat forces.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Frito-Lay Workers in Kansas Ratify Contract, Ending Strike
description: The workers at a Frito-Lay plant in Topeka went on strike this month to protest forced overtime and so-called suicide shifts, which they said left little time to sleep or see family members.
content: Hundreds of Frito-Lay employees ratified a contract on Saturday, ending a nearly three-week strike over forced overtime and long hours that many workers said had pushed them past the point of exhaustion, union officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: A Grandfather Died in ‘Swatting’ Over His Twitter Handle, Officials Say
description: Mark Herring had a fatal heart attack after the police swarmed his house after a fake emergency call. A Tennessee man was sentenced to five years in prison in connection with the episode.
content: Mark Herring was at home in Bethpage, Tenn., one night in April 2020 when the police swarmed his house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: And Still She Rises. And Rises. And Rises.
description: Simone Biles, the greatest gymnast of all time, who has used her influence to speak out against injustices, arrives at her second Olympics prepared to soar above the sport’s devastating recent history.
content: In the many months leading to this summer, Simone Biles couldn’t wait for the Tokyo Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: A Romanian Gymnast Chases Her Nation’s Legacy
description: In 2014, Larisa Iordache came closer than anyone to beating Simone Biles. That’s out now, but one last medal could help her reclaim Romania’s gymnastics glory after years of heartbreak.
content: Follow our live coverage of the women’s gymnastics Olympic qualifying round.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Sarah Kessler
title: Hosting the Olympics Is a Bad Deal
description: Even in normal times, the Games don’t pay off, argues the economist Andrew Zimbalist.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: American Dysfunction Is the Biggest Barrier to Fighting Covid
description: Lax vaccination and haphazard rules on masking sabotage the fight against the Delta variant in the U.S.
content: Globally, the Covid-19 pandemic is a threat because of scarcity of vaccines, with the highly transmissible Delta variant threatening millions around the world who can’t get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: This street skateboarder could deliver Japan’s first gold.
description: Yuto Horigome beat the American favorite Nyjah Huston at the worlds. Can he do it again at the Tokyo Olympics?
content: TOKYO — Past the baseball fields at Ojima Komatsugawa Park is a quiet edge where one of Japan’s leading Olympians got his start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Camps Have Been Scrambling for Counselors. Some Have Even Closed.
description: Summer camps have reopened into a tight labor market without the international seasonal workers they often depend on.
content: BOSTON — Joseph Charnock, like many parents, drew a sigh of relief when he dropped his 12-year-old daughter off for an eight-week session at Camp Quinebarge, on the shores of Lake Winnipesaukee in New Hampshire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: In Hungary, an Embattled L.G.B.T.Q. Community Takes to the Streets
description: Thousands of people attended the Budapest Pride march, defying efforts by the government of Prime Minister Viktor Orban to marginalize the country’s L.G.B.T.Q. community.
content: BUDAPEST — Defiant, colorful and proud, thousands of Hungarians marched through Budapest on Saturday to support the country’s embattled L.G.B.T.Q. community and to protest the far-right policies of Prime Minister Viktor Orban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: U.S. Moves to Drop Cases Against Chinese Researchers Accused of Hiding Military Ties
description: The arrests were part of a Trump-era initiative aimed at curbing Beijing’s efforts to steal intellectual property, corporate secrets, and military intelligence.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department moved this week to drop cases that it brought last year against five visiting researchers accused of hiding their ties to China’s military, prompting questions about the department’s efforts to combat Chinese national security threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: It Is Every American’s Right to Curse the President
description: A legal battle over the political signs in a New Jersey yard underscores broader threats to the freedom of speech in the United States.
content: There is little question that Gary Bundy, a municipal court judge in New Jersey, violated the constitutional rights of Andrea Dick this month by ordering her to remove three banners emblazoned with crude messages about President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Skateboarding Arrives at the Olympics: What to Watch For
description: Get ready for lots of impressive acrobatics and some of the youngest athletes at the Tokyo Games.
content: Skateboarding was added to the Olympics with the hope that it will instill the Summer Games with a jolt of youthful rebellion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrienne Matei
title: What Should Happen to Our Data When We Die?
description: Anthony Bourdain’s A.I.-generated voice is just the latest example of a celebrity being digitally reincarnated. These days, though, it could happen to any of us.
content: The new Anthony Bourdain documentary, “Roadrunner,” is one of many projects dedicated to the larger-than-life chef, writer and television personality. But the film has drawn outsize attention, in part because of its subtle reliance on artificial intelligence technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: They Waited, They Worried, They Stalled. This Week, They Got the Shot.
description: The U.S. vaccine rollout has plateaued and the course of the coronavirus pandemic in this country may depend on how many people are ultimately swayed to get vaccinated.
content: CHICAGO — They acknowledged that they could have showed up months ago. Many were satisfied that they were finally doing the right thing. A few grumbled that they had little choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: The U.S. soccer team bounced back with a ‘ruthless’ performance.
description: The United States dominated New Zealand from start to finish in a 6-1 victory.
content: SAITAMA, Japan — The first game just wasn’t good enough, the United States women’s soccer players declared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri and Andrew Das
title: The U.S. women’s soccer team files an opening brief in their ongoing equal pay lawsuit.
description: “We believe in our case and know our value,” Megan Rapinoe said in a statement. “It’s time the U.S.S.F. does too.”
content: The United States women’s soccer team filed its opening brief on Friday in an appeal of their ongoing equal pay lawsuit against the United States Soccer Federation, more than a year after a district court judge dismissed the team’s lawsuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles McDermid
title: They Were Once Luxury Venues. Now They Are Grim Covid Camps.
description: As an outbreak seizes Cambodia, patients who test positive for the virus say they are being forced into quarantine centers that are more like makeshift prisons than hospitals.
content: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — The patients sit in packed ambulances before passing through metal gates. Once they are inside, they get a number, like C07-22, a thin blanket and a bedsheet, which is meant to be a mosquito net. Lights shine bright at all hours for constant camera surveillance. Each person is given four bottles of water a day and three small meals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: What to Know About the Heat Wave
description: The forecast for the coming week suggests there will be few places in the contiguous United States to find relief.
content: A blast of hot air is forecast to raise temperatures across much of the contiguous United States in the coming week, adding another stretch of sweltering days to what has already been a punishing summer for many.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: A Long, Joyful Ride
description: You know you have a good job when it lets you try a jetpack. But after 21 years of thrills at The Times, it’s time for my next adventure: the classroom.
content: We were somewhere above south Louisiana’s wetlands when the helicopter door popped open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergio Olmos and Kristina Barker
title: Scenes From America’s Largest Wildfire
description: Small fires burned inside hollowed-out trees. Smoke rose from the blackened dirt. On the edge of the Bootleg Fire in southern Oregon, firefighters worked to halt the advance of the flames.
content: PAISLEY, Ore. — At the eastern edge of the Bootleg Fire on Friday afternoon, there was a surreal sign of the life that once existed in a patch of Oregon forest now turned to ash, smoke and leafless burnt trees: the murmurs of cattle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Hospitalized with Covid, a conservative Tennessee radio host shifts his message to urge vaccinations.
description: Phil Valentine is currently one of hundreds of Covid patients in Tennessee, which has seen a 77 percent increase in hospitalizations over the past two weeks.
content: A conservative radio host in Tennessee who had expressed unwillingness to be vaccinated is now hospitalized with Covid pneumonia and urging his listeners to get the shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Richard Carapaz of Ecuador prevails in one of the toughest road races in Olympic history.
description: Days after finishing third in the Tour de France, he won his country’s second-ever gold medal.
content: TOKYO — Six days after finishing third in the Tour de France, Richard Carapaz of Ecuador flew to Japan, battled the steamy conditions, pushed his body past exhaustion and won gold in the men’s road race on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Your Guide to Olympics Gymnastics: Vault
description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Tokyo, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
content: Women’s gymnastics is a marquee sport at the Summer Olympics, but otherwise doesn’t get much attention outside a dedicated group of fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: In the early medal table, the U.S. is in an unaccustomed spot: at the bottom.
description: It was a tough opening day for the U.S. in the 11 medal events. By early evening, all of the events were either over, or all the American entrants had been eliminated.
content: Ecuador won a medal on Saturday, the first day medals were awarded at these Summer Games. So did Kosovo, Thailand and Iran. Russia, which isn’t even exactly in the Games, won a medal as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Large Covid-related protests hit France, Italy and Australia.
description: Protesters’ targets include mandatory health passes in France and Italy, and lockdowns in Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide.
content: Over 160,000 demonstrators took to the streets in France on Saturday to protest the government’s Covid-19 health pass policy, with brief clashes between largely unmasked protesters and police officers in Paris followed by wafts of tear gas that were reminiscent of the Yellow Vest turmoil of several years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: U.S. soccer looks for a rebound against New Zealand.
description: The most remarkable thing about Sweden’s 3-0 victory over the United States on Wednesday was not the score or the stage but the nature of it: The United States was bullied and bossed around the field for the entire 90 minutes, the kind of beating this team usually delivers rather than receives.
content: The most remarkable thing about Sweden’s 3-0 victory over the United States on Wednesday was not the score or the stage but the nature of it: The United States was bullied and bossed around the field for the entire 90 minutes, the kind of beating this team usually delivers rather than receives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Katie Ledecky’s Unlikely New Role: Underdog?
description: Ariarne Titmus of Australia has been faster lately, even in one of Ledecky’s best races. How will the defending Olympic champion respond to the threat?
content: TOKYO — For nearly a decade, Katie Ledecky has lived a mostly blessed athletic existence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The youngest athlete at the Games, a 12-year-old Syrian, goes out in a loss in table tennis.
description: Hend Zaza lost on Saturday in straight sets to Liu Jia of Austria in the opening round of the women’s singles table tennis tournament.
content: TOKYO — After the final point, after all that she had been through, Hend Zaza, the youngest Olympian at the Tokyo Games, shed a tear.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Virus Surge Complicates Return-to-Office Plans
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 24, 2021.
content: “OK, you want me to put my life on the line to come back to the office, which will also decrease my productivity, and you’re not giving me any logic on why I actually need to do that?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Novak Djokovic wins his first match in punishing heat, after spells of dizziness in the sun.
description: Djokovic said he was dizzy at times on the sunny side of the court and suggested that organizers consider starting the matches a few hours later, allowing athletes to play into the evening.
content: Novak Djokovic resumed his quest for a “Golden Slam” and the Olympic gold medal Saturday, easily dispatching Hugo Dellien of Bolivia in straight sets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: The Olympic movement fails in supporting Black women, our columnist writes.
description: For better or worse, the Tokyo Olympics are finally here. And that means an extraordinary burden will fall again on the shoulders of a single group of athletes: Black women.
content: For better or worse, the Tokyo Olympics are finally here. And that means an extraordinary burden will fall again on the shoulders of a single group of athletes: Black women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Simone Biles and other teammates cheer on the U.S. men’s gymnasts as they advance.
description: TOKYO — Before Saturday’s qualification at the Tokyo Games, the men on the U.S. Olympic gymnastics team had their own pep rally.
content: TOKYO — Before Saturday’s qualification at the Tokyo Games, the men on the U.S. Olympic gymnastics team had their own pep rally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carina Chocano
title: I’m Obsessed With ‘Old.’ The Twist: I Won’t See It.
description: M. Night Shyamalan’s new movie has a trailer that eerily resonates with our strange times; and that’s enough for me.
content: Let me say up front that I do not expect to see M. Night Shyamalan’s latest movie, “Old,” which arrived in theaters last week, for no other reason than that I am traveling and haven’t set foot in a theater in almost two years. But in the past few weeks, I have watched its trailer over and over, enthralled by its combination of existential horror and unintended humor. The trailer introduces us to some people who become trapped on a remote beach, where they begin to age at an insanely accelerated pace. Naturally, they try to figure out what’s happening, floating theories and freaking out. This being a Shyamalan film, the trailer promises they will spend a lot of time looking confused and concerned — the same facial feat Mark Wahlberg sustained across the running time of “The Happening” — and yelling at one another, demanding explanations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California is a dominant athletic and cultural force at the Games.
description: You have probably heard it before: If California were its own country, it would rank fifth in an Olympic medal count.
content: You have probably heard it before: If California were its own country, it would rank fifth in an Olympic medal count.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: An Olympic beach volleyball match is decided by a Covid infection.
description: The match was not played because Marketa Slukova of the Czech Republic tested positive for the coronavirus. She is one of several members of the country’s Olympic team who are infected.
content: The effects of positive coronavirus tests among Olympic athletes began playing out on Saturday, hours after the opening ceremony, as a women’s beach volleyball team did not play because of an infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Apocalypse Right Now
description: Mother Nature called. She's had it.
content: WASHINGTON — Holy smokes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Split Decisions
description: We can divide and conquer Fred Piscop’s puzzle.
content: SPLIT DECISIONS — In the category of practice makes perfect, I have been trying to keep up with Fred Piscop’s site and solve more of this type of variety puzzle, one which has always been a weak spot for me. I’ve always been in the school of old dogs, new tricks, but something else has clicked: I think that my mind is taking a different tactic than it used to and it’s making me a lot faster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: Spain Pledged Citizenship to Sephardic Jews. Now They Feel Betrayed.
description: In 2015, Spain said it would give citizenship to the descendants of Sephardic Jews expelled during the Spanish Inquisition. Then rejections started pouring in this summer.
content: MADRID — María Sánchez, a retired mental health therapist in Albuquerque, spent the past four decades tracing her Jewish ancestry from Spain. She created a vast genealogical chart going back nearly 1,100 years, which included three ancestors who were tried in the Spanish Inquisition. Her findings even led her to join a synagogue in the 1980s and to become a practicing Jew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh and Hikari Hida
title: Fans were barred from the opening ceremony, but a few volunteers were ‘lucky to be here.’
description: TOKYO — Norie Kosaka knew better than to get her hopes up. A volunteer at the Games, she had been assigned to work at the opening ceremony on Friday night and assumed she would be one of the workers placed outside Olympic Stadium or tucked into some faraway corridor.
content: TOKYO — Norie Kosaka knew better than to get her hopes up. A volunteer at the Games, she had been assigned to work at the opening ceremony on Friday night and assumed she would be one of the workers placed outside Olympic Stadium or tucked into some faraway corridor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: 3x3 Basketball Is a New Sport, but It Already Has a G.O.A.T.
description: Since 2012, FIBA has organized six World Cup tournaments in three-on-three basketball. Dusan Bulut and his Serbian teammates have won four of them.
content: TOKYO — It all started with “White Men Can’t Jump.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Hikari Hida
title: The diversity of Japan’s team reflects a country that’s changing, slowly.
description: At least 35 members of the 583-strong Japanese Olympic team are multiracial. They are considered medal contenders in tennis and judo and will compete in boxing, sailing, sprinting, rugby and fencing, among other sports.
content: At least 35 members of the 583-strong Japanese Olympic team are multiracial. They are considered medal contenders in tennis and judo and will compete in boxing, sailing, sprinting, rugby and fencing, among other sports.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here’s a photo recap of Day 1 at the Olympics.
description: Twenty-three sports kicked off play on Saturday in Tokyo, including table tennis, gymnastics and swimming. Here are some of the best photos from the New York Times team on the ground.
content: Twenty-three sports kicked off play on Saturday in Tokyo, including table tennis, gymnastics and swimming. Here are some of the best photos from the New York Times team on the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Simone Biles headlines a star-studded lineup.
description: Two words: Simone Biles.
content: Two words: Simone Biles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Nyjah Huston’s long, strange skateboard trip to the Olympics.
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif. — Nyjah Huston was driving his Mercedes coupe well past the speed limit between his $3 million house overlooking the Pacific Ocean and his private indoor skatepark where he was training for the Olympics.
content: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif. — Nyjah Huston was driving his Mercedes coupe well past the speed limit between his $3 million house overlooking the Pacific Ocean and his private indoor skatepark where he was training for the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Amateur Fossil Hunters Make Rare Find in U.K. Using Google Earth
description: While some indulged in baking through lockdown, a husband-and-wife team discovered an exceptionally large and well-preserved group of Jurassic starfish.
content: LONDON — Millions of years before the Cotswolds, in western England, became a popular vacation destination, romanticized for its ancient woodlands, honey-colored stone villages and medieval abbeys, it was a shallow, warm sea, home to a Jurassic marine ecosystem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: A Rebellion Is Stirring in Boris Johnson’s Backyard
description: Brexit helped destroy Labour’s “red wall” in England’s North. Now, it’s coming for the Conservatives’ “blue wall” in the South.
content: TUDELEY, England — Hugh Patterson could sense victory when he ran in local elections this year even though this area of rolling countryside, picturesque pubs and pricey rustic homes was a stronghold for his opponent from Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s Conservative Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Katie Ledecky may finally have a true challenger.
description: The U.S. swimmer Katie Ledecky’s domination is so routine that her surname has become a verb, synonymous with crushing the competition. For nearly a decade, she has ledeckied away in her specialties — distance swims longer than 400 meters — rarely facing a true challenger and certainly nothing resembling a rival.
content: The U.S. swimmer Katie Ledecky’s domination is so routine that her surname has become a verb, synonymous with crushing the competition. For nearly a decade, she has ledeckied away in her specialties — distance swims longer than 400 meters — rarely facing a true challenger and certainly nothing resembling a rival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: The Olympic flame had a tortuous journey to the ceremony.
description: The Olympic torch has had a lonely journey to the opening ceremony.
content: The Olympic torch has had a lonely journey to the opening ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Can the Left Regulate Sex?
description: Cultural progressives need to choose between using their new power for liberation or regulation.
content: There is a harrowing story in The New Yorker that everyone should grit their teeth and read. Written by Rachel Aviv, it tells the story of how a respected German psychologist named Helmut Kentler decided to foster neglected children with pedophiles, how he ran this experiment with government support for decades after the 1960s, and how it created exactly the kind of hells you would expect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Kohei Uchimura, Japan’s gymnastics hero, slips, falls and loses out on a medal.
description: Considered one of the best male gymnasts ever, Uchimura failed to qualify for the horizontal bar finals at his home Olympics.
content: TOKYO — Nearly everyone in the gymnastics arena — other gymnasts, coaches, arena workers and reporters — stopped what they were doing on Saturday to watch Kohei Uchimura of Japan, considered one of the best male gymnasts ever, perform his horizontal bar routine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Is the Hamptons Party Moving to Springs?
description: The artsy and quieter hamlet of the Hamptons has seen an influx of Manhattanites, buzzy restaurants and even celebrities.
content: Rita Cantina, a festive Mexican restaurant in the Hamptons, has been getting a lot of attention since opening this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: An Algerian judoka was suspended after withdrawing to avoid meeting an Israeli opponent.
description: The Olympic judo competition found itself mired in a political controversy even before Saturday’s start at the Nippon Budokan.
content: The Olympic judo competition found itself mired in a political controversy even before Saturday’s start at the Nippon Budokan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: For Yuto Horigome, a Gold Medal Could Change Everything
description: The son of a taxi driver, the top rival to the American Nyjah Huston knows a gold medal could burnish his sport’s renegade reputation in Japan.
content: TOKYO — Past the baseball fields at Ojima Komatsugawa Park, which on Friday were full of uniformed boys, is a quiet edge where one of Japan’s leading Olympians got his start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Morse
title: U.S. broadcast coverage includes gymnastics, tennis and swimming.
description: Simone Biles is set to compete in four events.
content: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage for Sunday, including women’s gymnastics and the next game for the seemingly unstoppable softball team. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Hikari Hida
title: Japan’s Diverse Olympic Stars Reflect a Country That’s Changing (Slowly)
description: Multiracial athletes like Naomi Osaka and Rui Hachimura are helping to redefine what it means to be Japanese. But they are often still seen as outsiders.
content: TOKYO — When the Japanese Olympic team marched at the opening ceremony in Tokyo on Friday, towering over the rest of the delegation was the flag-bearer Rui Hachimura, a rising N.B.A. star who was born and raised in Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Star Search
description: Chandi Deitmer’s dazzling debut goes right over our heads.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s complex creation is a debut from Chandi Deitmer, a social worker in the fields of psychiatry and geriatrics, who got into solving via The Onion, back when you could get a free copy from a box on the corner. (Those were fun puzzles and there’s very little digital evidence of them, unfortunately.) She started constructing only a couple of years ago, mainly for independent puzzle publications, which are great venues for constructors and solvers alike — a chance to catch new talent coming up, or solve a puzzle by a constructor you know and like that doesn’t go into the Times’s rotation. In this case, Ms. Deitmer’s debut was with The Inkubator; try it here, if you’re enamored with today’s solve. After all, the title of this puzzle is “Star Search!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: A Son of Gabriel García Márquez Tenderly Recalls His Parents
description: In “A Farewell to Gabo and Mercedes,” Rodrigo Garcia chronicles his parents’ final days, including his celebrated father’s struggle with dementia and his mother’s fierce independence to the end.
content: A FAREWELL TO GABO AND MERCEDES A Son’s Memoir of Gabriel García Márquez and Mercedes BarchaBy Rodrigo Garcia
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Your Guide to Olympics Gymnastics: Balance Beam
description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Tokyo, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
content: Women’s gymnastics is a marquee sport at the Summer Olympics, but otherwise doesn’t get much attention outside a dedicated group of fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Is That Stroller in the Hallway Really a Safety Hazard?
description: New York City’s fire code is clear on the subject of hallway safety, even if it’s not what many parents want to hear.
content: Q: I live on the third floor of a small rent-stabilized walk-up building in the East Village. I have a 1-year-old baby, and have been leaving my stroller at the landing near the bottom of the stairs since he was born. No one complained until a new tenant moved in and told the landlord that the stroller is a tripping hazard. Now the landlord is telling me to move the stroller, but carrying it and my baby up two flights of stairs seems dangerous. What can I do? And what would happen if I ignored the complaints?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: What to Watch as Baseball and Softball Return to the Olympics
description: The sports are back after a 13-year absence, with just six countries competing in each. Here’s how the tournaments work.
content: For the first time in 13 years, baseball and softball will be contested at the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Cecilia Kang
title: Biden’s Antitrust Team Signals a Big Swing at Corporate Titans
description: The president has stacked his administration with crusaders who have spent their careers challenging corporate consolidation.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden has assembled the most aggressive antitrust team in decades, stacking his administration with three legal crusaders as it prepares to take on corporate consolidation and market power with efforts that could include blocking mergers and breaking up big companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: A typhoon forecast roils the rowing schedule at the Olympics.
description: The U.S. team said the schedule was being adjusted because of an “inclement weather forecast.” Reports show that a storm could hit the Tokyo region on Tuesday.
content: Tokyo 2020 can’t seem to catch a break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Takato dominates in judo, giving Japan its first gold medal at the Games.
description: Host countries often outperform at the Olympics, and Japan wasted no time capturing its first gold medal at the Tokyo 2020 Games, appropriately enough in judo, a sport the Japanese dominate.
content: Host countries often outperform at the Olympics, and Japan wasted no time capturing its first gold medal at the Tokyo 2020 Games, appropriately enough in judo, a sport the Japanese dominate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Blunt End?
description: Adam Aaronson and Ricky Cruz bare all in a tricky Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a fun themeless grid from a couple of the youngs (Adam Aaronson and Ricky Cruz, in their first Times collaboration). It introduces itself with a trendy debut, but there’s a lot of well-played crunch inside that will appeal to lovers of the classics. I got pretty tangled up in the northeast corner, double-crossed by a slew of misdirects, and I’m curious to see what slowed down other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: The Most Influential Spreader of Coronavirus Misinformation Online
description: Researchers and regulators say Joseph Mercola, an osteopathic physician, creates and profits from misleading claims about Covid-19 vaccines.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The article that appeared online on Feb. 9 began with a seemingly innocuous question about the legal definition of vaccines. Then over its next 3,400 words, it declared coronavirus vaccines were “a medical fraud” and said the injections did not prevent infections, provide immunity or stop transmission of the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tokyo Olympics, Day 1: The Games Get Rolling
description: The U.S. women’s soccer team found some answers, and a new sport made its Olympic debut.
content: The U.S. women’s soccer team found some answers, and a new sport made its Olympic debut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful and The Associated Press
title: Anti-Lockdown Protesters Clash with Police in Sydney
description: Defying a statewide stay-at-home order, 3,500 mostly maskless protesters marched downtown in Australia’s largest city, a sometimes violent rally that raised fears an outbreak driven by the Delta variant might worsen.
content: Defying a statewide stay-at-home order, 3,500 mostly maskless protesters marched downtown in Australia’s largest city, a sometimes violent rally that raised fears an outbreak driven by the Delta variant might worsen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Thousands Rally for Equality at Budapest Pride March
description: A Pride celebration in Hungary on Saturday doubled as a protest of Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s far-right policies, which have marginalized the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
content: A Pride celebration in Hungary on Saturday doubled as a protest of Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s far-right policies, which have marginalized the L.G.B.T.Q. community.

title: Corrections: July 24, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 24, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about flooded subways misidentified the nonprofit organization where Bernardo Baranda Sepúlveda works as a researcher. It is the Institute for Transportation and Development Policy, not the Institute for Transport Development.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Where People With Disabilities Do Best
description: Readers react to an essay by David Axelrod about how his daughter has thrived in an institution.
